properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Boroka Track, west of Halls Gap
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Boroka Track, west of Halls Gap. 
  • The bushfire at Boroka Track, Grampians National Park is under control.
  • Due to works to repair access to the area, Boroka Track and Lookout will remain close.

Many popular sites in the Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park are open, however areas affected by fire are closed as they remain extremely dangerous. Fines may apply if you are found behind road and walking track closures.  

For details on access to the park, visit the ParksVic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap. Halls Gap and surrounding towns are open. 

Plan your trip before you leave - visit VicTraffic.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

This will be the final message for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Many popular sites in the Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park are open, however areas affected by fire are closed as they remain extremely dangerous. Fines may apply if you are found behind road and walking track closures. For details on access to the park, visit the ParksVic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap. Halls Gap and surrounding towns are open. Plan your trip before you leave - visit VicTraffic. There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Dimboola, Pimpinio, Wail.

  • There is a bushfire at Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Little Desert in an easterly direction and is impacting Dimboola. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now. 
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Evacuate Immediately warning  issued at 9:25 PM. 
  • If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 

The following roads are closed: 
  • Nhill-Harrow Road.
  • The Western Highway between Dimboola and Horsham
  • The Western Highway between Dimboola and Nhill
  • Borung Highway between Dimboola and Cannum
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire. 
Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 06:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:

Incident Location: Little Desert National Park
Issue Date: Monday 27 January 2025, 11:57 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 28 January 2025, 06:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/35973/moreinfo

This Emergency Warning is being issued for Dimboola, Pimpinio, Wail.

- There is a bushfire at Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control.
- The bushfire is travelling from Little Desert in an easterly direction and is impacting Dimboola. 
- This fire is threatening homes and lives.
- It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now. 
- This Emergency Warning replaces the Evacuate Immediately warning  issued at 9:25 PM. 
- If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.


        You are in danger and need   to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take   shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas of the Grampians National Park affected by fire.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas of the Grampians National Park affected by fire.
  • The status of the bushfire in the Grampians National Park is now Under Control.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 3.03pm Thursday 16 January.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
 
Many popular sites in the Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park are open, however areas affected by fire are closed as they remain extremely dangerous. Fines may apply if you are found behind road and walking track closures.  

For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.

Halls Gap and surrounding towns are open. Businesses and the community are welcoming visitors back to the area. 

Plan your trip before you leave - visit VicTraffic.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 
Recovery and resilience
If you have been or may be impacted by bushfire, it is understandable if you are feeling concerned and experiencing a mix of strong mental, emotional or physical reactions right now. For emergency relief information during major incidents, call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226 or visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief
Impacts in your area: 
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Many popular sites in the Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park are open, however areas affected by fire are closed as they remain extremely dangerous. Fines may apply if you are found behind road and walking track closures. For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap. Halls Gap and surrounding towns are open. Businesses and the community are welcoming visitors back to the area. Plan your trip before you leave - visit VicTraffic. There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Grampians, Mirranatwa, Victoria Valley. 
  • There is a bushfire at Victoria Valley Bullawin Rd that is out of control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bullawin Road in a north-easterly direction towards Mirranatwa. The fire started near Bullawin road in Victoria Valley.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bullawin Road has been impacted and access  may not be possible. 
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
This messages was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cranage, Zumsteins.
  • There is a bushfire in the areas near Asses Ears Road, Taylors Track and Launders Track in the northern part of the Grampians National Park that are not yet under control.
  • The fires started after lightning strikes in the area and is moving in a north easterly direction.
Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Horsham or Halls Gap.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 08:10 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Arkona, Dahlen, Dart Dart, Grass Flat, Kiata East, Nhill, Nurcoung, Salisbury, Vectis East, Dimboola, Duchembegarra, Mitre, Murra Warra, Natimuk, Pimpinio, Wail
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Arkona, Dahlen, Dart Dart, Dimboola, Duchembegarra, Grass Flat, Kiata East, Mitre, Murra Warra, Natimuk, Nhill, Nurcoung, Pimpinio, Salisbury, Vectis East, Wail.
  • There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire is travelling in an easterly direction towards Dimboola, and northerly direction towards Nhill. 
  • This is an active and dynamic fire that is spreading rapidly. 
  • This fire creating a large amount of smoke that can be seen and smelt over a long distance. 
  • The townships of Dimboola and Pimpinio are being evacuated along with the Wail area. 
You should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Western Highway is closed from Dimboola to Nhill.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 06:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Grampians, Strachans. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Grampians, Strachans. 
  • The bushfire at Bullawin Road is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bullawin road in a north-easterly direction. 
It is NOT SAFE to return to Strachan's Campground. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning. 

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 09:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Cooack, Duchembegarra, Little Desert, Dimboola, Goroke, Grass Flat, Lawloit, Nurcoung, Peronne, Pimpinio, Wail
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cooack, Dimboola, Duchembegarra, Goroke, Grass Flat, Lawloit, Little Desert, Nurcoung, Peronne, Pimpinio, Wail.
  • There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire is travelling in an easterly direction towards Dimboola and Wail. 
  • This is an active and dynamic fire that is spreading rapidly and is likely to extend further. 
  • This fire creating a large amount of smoke that can be seen and smelt over a long distance. 
  • The townships of Dimboola and Pimpinio are being evacuated along with the Wail area. 
Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
What you should do: 
  • Visitors and campers should leave the national park. 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Western Highway is closed from Dimboola to Nhill
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 05:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - BUSHFIRE - Leave Now
Incident Location: Little Desert National Park - Sand Track
Issue Date: Monday 27 January 2025, 09:28 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 28 January 2025, 05:30 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/35965/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cooack, Dimboola, Duchembegarra, Goroke, Grass Flat, Lawloit, Little Desert, Nurcoung, Peronne, Pimpinio, Wail.
- There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
- The fire is travelling in an easterly direction towards Dimboola and Wail. 
- This is an active and dynamic fire that is spreading rapidly and is likely to extend further. 
- This fire creating a large amount of smoke that can be seen and smelt over a long distance.  
- The townships of Dimboola and Pimpinio are being evacuated along with the Wail area. 


Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Driffield, Narracan, Ten Mile Creek. 
  • There is a bushfire at Morwell-Thorpdale Rd, Driffield that is under control.
  • Firefighters will remain on site to patrol this fire overnight.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 7.00pm Monday 27 January 2025.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 09:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Goroke, Minimay, Peronne.
  • There is a grassfire at Fire Minimay - Diggers Lane, Minimay that is under control.
  • This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act message issued earlier today. 
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are attending to this fire. 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • NBN connected phone and internet services will not work during a power outage. You will not be able to call Triple Zero (000) using your home phone. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 09:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Gerang Gerung, Kiata, Kinimakatka, Lawloit, Winiam, Winiam East, Little Desert, Miram
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Gerang Gerung, Kiata, Kinimakatka, Lawloit, Little Desert, Miram, Winiam, Winiam East.

  • There is a bushfire at Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Little Desert National Park in a northerly direction towards Nhill.  
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now. 
  • If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 05:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

        You are in danger and need   to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take   shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Glenisla Crossing, Wartook, Flat Rock Crossing, Brimpaen
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Brimpaen, Glenisla Crossing, Wartook, Flat Rock Crossing.
  • There are bushfires in the areas near Asses Ears Road, Taylors Track and Launders Track in the northern part of the Grampians National Park that are not yet under control.
  • The fires started after lightning strikes in the area and is travelling in a north-easterly direction.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 6.51pm.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 28/01/2025 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
